content:
ListBox+SelectedIndexCollection Class

In this Article

Represents the collection containing the indexes to the selected items in a ListBox.

Syntax

Declaration

public class ListBox.SelectedIndexCollection : System.Collections.IList

Inheritance Hierarchy

  • System.Object
  • ListBox+SelectedIndexCollection

Inherited Members

Equals(Object)
,
Equals(Object,Object)
,
GetHashCode()
,
GetType()
,
MemberwiseClone()
,
ReferenceEquals(Object,Object)
,
ToString()

Remarks

The ListBox.SelectedIndexCollection class stores the indexes to the selected items in the ListBox. The indexes stored in the ListBox.SelectedIndexCollection are index positions within the ListBox+ObjectCollection class. The ListBox+ObjectCollection class stores all items displayed in the ListBox.

The following table is an example of how the ListBox+ObjectCollection stores the items of the ListBox as well as their selection states within an example ListBox.

Index Item Selection state within the ListBox
0 object1 Unselected
1 object2 Selected
2 object3 Unselected
3 object4 Selected
4 object5 Selected

Based on the ListBox+ObjectCollection example in the previous table, the following table demonstrates how the ListBox.SelectedIndexCollection would appear.

Index Index of selected item in ObjectCollection
0 1
1 3
2 4

You can use the properties and methods of this class to perform a variety of tasks with the collection. The Contains method enables you to determine whether an index position from the ListBox+ObjectCollection class is a member of the selected indexes stored in the ListBox.SelectedIndexCollection. Once you know that the item is located within the collection, you can use the IndexOf method to determine where a specific index position within the ListBox+ObjectCollection for the ListBox is stored.

Adds the ListBox at the specified index location.
Clear()

Removes all controls from the collection.

Determines whether the specified index is located within the collection.
CopyTo(Array,Int32)

Copies the entire collection into an existing array at a specified location within the array.
GetEnumerator()

Returns an enumerator to use to iterate through the selected indexes collection.
IndexOf(Int32)

Returns the index within the ListBox+SelectedIndexCollection of the specified index from the ListBox+ObjectCollection of the ListBox.
Remove(Int32)

Removes the specified control from the collection.

Constructors

  • ListBox+SelectedIndexCollection(ListBox)

    Initializes a new instance of the ListBox+SelectedIndexCollection class.

    public SelectedIndexCollection (System.Windows.Forms.ListBox owner);

    Parameters

    • owner
      ListBox

      A ListBox representing the owner of the collection.

    Remarks

    You cannot create an instance of this class without associating it with a ListBox control.

Properties

  • Count

    Gets the number of items in the collection.

    public int Count { get; }

    Property Value

    • Int32

      The number of items in the collection.

    Remarks

    This property enables you to determine the number of selected items in the ListBox. You can then use this value when looping through the values of the collection and you need to provide a number of iterations to perform the loop. Unless the SelectionMode property of the ListBox is set to SelectionMode.MultiSimple or SelectionMode.MultiExtended, this property always returns a value of zero (0) or one (1) depending on whether you have a selected item.

    Example

    The following example demonstrates how to use the FindString method to search for all instances of the search text in the items of the ListBox. The example uses the version of the FindString method that enables you to specify a starting search index from which to do a continual search of all items in the ListBox. The example also demonstrates how to determine when the FindString method begins searching from the top of the list after it reaches the bottom of the list of items to prevent a recursive search. Once items are found in the ListBox, they are selected using the SetSelected method. 

    private:
   void FindAllOfMyString( String^ searchString )
   {
      // Set the SelectionMode property of the ListBox to select multiple items.
      listBox1->SelectionMode = SelectionMode::MultiExtended;

      // Set our intial index variable to -1.
      int x = -1;

      // If the search string is empty exit.
      if ( searchString->Length != 0 )
      {
         // Loop through and find each item that matches the search string.
         do
         {
            // Retrieve the item based on the previous index found. Starts with -1 which searches start.
            x = listBox1->FindString( searchString, x );

            // If no item is found that matches exit.
            if ( x != -1 )
            {
               // Since the FindString loops infinitely, determine if we found first item again and exit.
               if ( listBox1->SelectedIndices->Count > 0 )
               {
                  if ( x == listBox1->SelectedIndices[ 0 ] )
                                    return;
               }

               // Select the item in the ListBox once it is found.
               listBox1->SetSelected( x, true );
            }
         }
         while ( x != -1 );
      }
   }

          private void FindAllOfMyString(string searchString)
      {
         // Set the SelectionMode property of the ListBox to select multiple items.
         listBox1.SelectionMode = SelectionMode.MultiExtended;
         
         // Set our intial index variable to -1.
         int x =-1;
         // If the search string is empty exit.
         if (searchString.Length != 0)
         {
            // Loop through and find each item that matches the search string.
            do
            {
               // Retrieve the item based on the previous index found. Starts with -1 which searches start.
               x = listBox1.FindString(searchString, x);
               // If no item is found that matches exit.
               if (x != -1)
               {
                  // Since the FindString loops infinitely, determine if we found first item again and exit.
                  if (listBox1.SelectedIndices.Count > 0)
                  {
                     if(x == listBox1.SelectedIndices[0])
                        return;
                  }
                  // Select the item in the ListBox once it is found.
                  listBox1.SetSelected(x,true);
               }
   
            }while(x != -1);
         }
      }

       Private Sub FindAllOfMyString(ByVal searchString As String)
      ' Set the SelectionMode property of the ListBox to select multiple items.
      listBox1.SelectionMode = SelectionMode.MultiExtended

      ' Set our intial index variable to -1.
      Dim x As Integer = -1
      ' If the search string is empty exit.
      If searchString.Length <> 0 Then
         ' Loop through and find each item that matches the search string.
         Do
            ' Retrieve the item based on the previous index found. Starts with -1 which searches start.
            x = listBox1.FindString(searchString, x)
            ' If no item is found that matches exit.
            If x <> -1 Then
               ' Since the FindString loops infinitely, determine if we found first item again and exit.
               If ListBox1.SelectedIndices.Count > 0 Then
                  If x = ListBox1.SelectedIndices(0) Then
                     Return
                  End If
               End If
               ' Select the item in the ListBox once it is found.
               ListBox1.SetSelected(x, True)
            End If
         Loop While x <> -1
      End If
   End Sub
  • IsReadOnly

    Gets a value indicating whether the collection is read-only.

    public bool IsReadOnly { get; }

    Property Value

    • Boolean

      true if the collection is read-only; otherwise, false.

    Remarks

    This property is always true for this collection. The items in this collection are modified only by the ListBox control.

  • Item(Int32)

    Gets the index value at the specified index within this collection.

    public int this[int index] { get; }

    Parameters

    • index
      Int32

      The index of the item in the collection to get.

    Property Value

    • Int32

      The index value from the ListBox+ObjectCollection that is stored at the specified location.

    Exceptions

    • ArgumentOutOfRangeException

      The index parameter is less than zero or greater than or equal to the value of the stem.Windows.Forms.ListBox.SelectedIndexCollection.Count* property of the ListBox+SelectedIndexCollection class.

    Remarks

    This indexer enables you to get a specific selected index from the ListBox+SelectedIndexCollection. The index stored in the collection is an index into the ListBox+ObjectCollection of the ListBox that represents a selected item in the ListBox.

Methods

  • Add(Int32)

    Adds the ListBox at the specified index location.

    public void Add (int index);

    Parameters

    • index
      Int32

      The location in the array at which to add the ListBox.

  • Clear()

    Removes all controls from the collection.

    public void Clear ();
  • Contains(Int32)

    Determines whether the specified index is located within the collection.

    public bool Contains (int selectedIndex);

    Parameters

    • selectedIndex
      Int32

      The index to locate in the collection.

    Returns

    • Boolean

      true if the specified index from the ListBox+ObjectCollection for the ListBox is an item in this collection; otherwise, false.

    Remarks

    The Contains method enables you to determine whether an index position from the ListBox+ObjectCollection class is a member of the selected indexes stored in the ListBox+SelectedIndexCollection. You can use this to determine whether a specific item in a multiple-selection ListBox is selected.

  • CopyTo(Array,Int32)

    Copies the entire collection into an existing array at a specified location within the array.

    public void CopyTo (Array destination, int index);

    Parameters

    • destination
      Array

      The destination array.

    • index
      Int32

      The index in the destination array at which storing begins.

    Remarks

    You can use this method to combine the selected indexes from multiple collections into a single array.

  • GetEnumerator()

    Returns an enumerator to use to iterate through the selected indexes collection.

    public System.Collections.IEnumerator GetEnumerator ();

    Returns

    • IEnumerator

      An IEnumerator that represents the selected indexes collection.

  • IndexOf(Int32)

    Returns the index within the ListBox+SelectedIndexCollection of the specified index from the ListBox+ObjectCollection of the ListBox.

    public int IndexOf (int selectedIndex);

    Parameters

    • selectedIndex
      Int32

      The zero-based index from the ListBox+ObjectCollection to locate in this collection.

    Returns

    • Int32

      The zero-based index in the collection where the specified index of the ListBox+ObjectCollection was located within the ListBox+SelectedIndexCollection; otherwise, negative one (-1).

    Remarks

    Once you know that an item is located within the collection (using the Contains method), you can use the IndexOf method to determine where a specific index position within the ListBox+ObjectCollection for the ListBox is stored within the ListBox+SelectedIndexCollection.

  • Remove(Int32)

    Removes the specified control from the collection.

    public void Remove (int index);

    Parameters

    • index
      Int32

      The control to be removed.

Explicit Interface Implementations

  • ICollection.IsSynchronized

    For a description of this member, see stem.Collections.ICollection.IsSynchronized*.

    bool System.Collections.ICollection.IsSynchronized { get; }

    Returns

    • Boolean

      false in all cases.

    Remarks

    This member is an explicit interface member implementation. It can be used only when the ListBox+SelectedIndexCollection instance is cast to an ICollection interface.

  • ICollection.SyncRoot

    For a description of this member, see stem.Collections.ICollection.SyncRoot*.

    object System.Collections.ICollection.SyncRoot { get; }

    Returns

    • System.Object

      An object that can be used to synchronize access to the ListBox+SelectedIndexCollection.

    Remarks

    This member is an explicit interface member implementation. It can be used only when the ListBox+SelectedIndexCollection instance is cast to an ICollection interface.

  • IList.Add(Object)

    For a description of this member, see stem.Collections.IList.Add*.

    int IList.Add (object value);

    Parameters

    • value
      System.Object

      The index to add to the collection.

    Returns

    • Int32

      The position into which the index was inserted.

    Remarks

    This member is an explicit interface member implementation. It can be used only when the ListBox+SelectedIndexCollection instance is cast to an IList interface.

    You cannot change the ListBox+SelectedIndexCollection class directly. To add an item to the ListBox+SelectedIndexCollection, use the SelectedIndex property or the SetSelected method.

  • IList.Clear()

    For a description of this member, see stem.Collections.IList.Clear*.

    void IList.Clear ();

    Remarks

    This member is an explicit interface member implementation. It can be used only when the ListBox+SelectedIndexCollection instance is cast to an IList interface.

  • IList.Contains(Object)

    For a description of this member, see stem.Collections.IList.Contains*.

    bool IList.Contains (object selectedIndex);

    Parameters

    • selectedIndex
      System.Object

      The index to locate in the collection.

    Returns

    • Boolean

      true if the specified index from the ListBox+ObjectCollection for the ListBox is an item in this collection; otherwise, false.

    Remarks

    This member is an explicit interface member implementation. It can be used only when the ListBox+SelectedIndexCollection instance is cast to an IList interface.

    The IList.Contains method enables you to determine whether an index position from the ListBox+ObjectCollection a member of the selected indexes stored in the ListBox+SelectedIndexCollection. You can use this method to determine whether a specific item in a multiple-selection list box is selected.

  • IList.IndexOf(Object)

    For a description of this member, see stem.Collections.IList.IndexOf*.

    int IList.IndexOf (object selectedIndex);

    Parameters

    • selectedIndex
      System.Object

      The zero-based index from the ListBox+ObjectCollection to locate in this collection.

    Returns

    • Int32

      The zero-based index in the collection where the specified index of the ListBox+ObjectCollection is located if it is in the ListBox+SelectedIndexCollection; otherwise, -1.

    Remarks

    This member is an explicit interface member implementation. It can be used only when the ListBox+SelectedIndexCollection instance is cast to an IList interface.

    The ListBox+SelectedIndexCollection contains the indexes of selected items in the ListBox+ObjectCollection of the ListBox control.

  • IList.Insert(Int32,Object)

    For a description of this member, see stem.Collections.IList.Insert*.

    void IList.Insert (int index, object value);

    Parameters

    • index

      The index at which value should be inserted.

      System.Object

      The object to be added to the ListBox+SelectedIndexCollection.

    Exceptions

    • NotSupportedException

      Always thrown.

    Remarks

    This member is an explicit interface member implementation. It can be used only when the ListBox+SelectedIndexCollection instance is cast to an IList interface.

    You cannot change the ListBox+SelectedIndexCollection class directly. To add an item to the ListBox+SelectedIndexCollection, use the SelectedItem property or the SetSelected method.
